stream_context.summary: The stream focused on developing the 'Oil Rig' level. Key activities included brainstorming and designing a boss fight for an oil-based Blarg, redesigning the level's structure to make it feel larger via an underwater travel system, and pivoting on the design of a central Bowser's office building from an explorable castle to a visual setpiece.

development_findings.summary: The project is currently in a polishing phase, which includes remaking older, smaller 'retro areas' to match the quality of newer ones.
To make the Oil Rig level feel larger and less linear, Kaze decided to add an interconnected underwater area accessible from multiple points, serving as a form of quick travel.
The boss for the Oil Rig level will be a gargantuan Blarg made of oil, inspired by Yoshi's Island to maintain thematic consistency.
The oil Blarg boss fight will center on a unique mechanic where Mario rides a bar of soap to chase and 'clean' the boss, causing it to shrink until defeated.
development_findings.quote: Honestly, that sounds like a shitpost idea but at the same time, I kind of like it.

development_findings.summary: The design for Bowser's office on the Oil Rig pivoted from a large, explorable castle to a tall, inaccessible tower to avoid creating a 'red herring' with little gameplay.
Kaze prioritizes keeping the player in control of Mario's core moveset and avoids mechanics like controlling a crane, which he feels is a common flaw in other ROM hacks.
The game's physics are intentionally designed to be very different from the original Mario 64, which will require speedrunners to unlearn their established muscle memory.
The game will be open-sourced, but only after the official release to prevent spoilers and mitigate potential legal issues with Nintendo.
A secret 'Magic Show' easter egg is planned, where Bowser will perform bad magic tricks and tell terrible jokes.
An update to the project's 'libultra things' broke the existing cannon camera, which now needs to be completely remade.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that individuals with immense wealth cease to be human and become entities, using Elon Musk as an example.
context_findings.quote: Elon Musk is not a person, he's an entity.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for games like Pikmin 2 that he feels lack player freedom and meaningful choice, contrasting it with his enjoyment of Tears of the Kingdom's emergent gameplay.
context_findings.quote: You have no freedom. You're basically just like a worker drone. You're not actually playing a game. You're just doing what you're being told.

context_findings.summary: Kaze claims he is no longer concerned about legal action from Nintendo, stating he has successfully contested their YouTube claims and adopted a defiant stance.
context_findings.quote: Last time they took me down, I told them to fuck off, basically, and they did fuck off.

context_findings.summary: The project is developed in Kaze's free time outside of his full-time job as a programmer, and he dedicates his days off to working on it.
context_findings.quote: I do have a full-time job so I can't spend that much time on it... Yeah, that's what I do on my day off, I work.

context_findings.summary: The game has been in development for nearly three years and is estimated to be two-thirds complete, with a realistic release at least a year and a half away.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides mock-ups for visual elements like atmospheric effects, which Kaze then evaluates for technical feasibility.
Kaze states that Biobak reviews and improves his 3D models after they are created, which is a key part of their workflow and has significantly improved the game's visual quality.
biobak.quote: That is part of the reason that this looks so much better than the demo.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for character animations, such as creating the walk and shell animations for the Buzzy Beetle NPCs.
Zeina actively participates in the stream from the background, offering help, commentary, and humor, such as joking about Kaze's 3D models.
zeina.quote: I'm usually just helping him doing stuff.

key_stories.title: The Oil Blarg and the Soap
key_stories.summary: The team needed a boss for the Oil Rig level. After brainstorming, they settled on an oil-based Blarg from Yoshi's Island and devised a unique and comical combat mechanic involving Mario riding a bar of soap to clean and defeat the boss.
key_stories.challenge: Designing a thematically appropriate boss for the Oil Rig level and creating a unique combat mechanic that avoids common ROM hack design pitfalls.
key_stories.process: The team brainstormed various minions, settling on a Blarg from Yoshi's Island to fit the theme. When considering how to defeat it, the idea of using soap emerged. This evolved into a chase mechanic where Mario rides a soap bar to damage the boss.
key_stories.outcome: A fully conceptualized boss fight against an oil-based Blarg. The mechanic involves Mario riding a bar of soap to 'clean' the boss, a silly but fitting solution that keeps the player in control and is tutorialized within the level itself.
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly, that sounds like a shitpost idea but at the same time, I kind of like it.

key_stories.title: Expanding the Oil Rig
key_stories.summary: Kaze felt the Oil Rig level was too small and linear. His solution was to add a new dimension to it: a series of interconnected underwater rooms accessible from multiple points on the rig, which functions as a quick-travel system and adds exploration value.
key_stories.challenge: The initial design for the Oil Rig level felt too linear and small, lacking sufficient exploration and content.
key_stories.process: Kaze recognized that his current plan for the level was too simple. To add depth without scrapping the layout, he proposed adding multiple entrances to a new area below the main rig, linking disparate points and encouraging exploration.
key_stories.outcome: The level design was expanded by adding a new interconnected 'underwater' sub-area. This section acts as a hub or quick-travel system, making the level feel larger and providing new spaces for secrets like the 8-bit pipe.
key_stories.key_quote: The world feels too small if I just go with my current plan... If we add entrances to go into the underwater area like all over the place and you could go from place to place I think that would add a lot.

key_stories.title: The Bowser's Office Pivot
key_stories.summary: Kaze initially designed an explorable Bowser's office building but realized it would be mostly empty, a 'red herring' for players. After community feedback, he pivoted the design to be a tall, inaccessible tower, serving as a more efficient and effective visual setpiece.
key_stories.challenge: The design for Bowser's office was a large, explorable building with very little planned gameplay, creating a potential 'red herring' that could disappoint players.
key_stories.process: Kaze modeled an initial concept for the building. After feedback from the community (including jokes that it looked like a toilet) and his own reflection, he agreed that an explorable but empty building was poor design and pivoted to making it a non-interactive setpiece.
key_stories.outcome: The design was changed from an explorable castle to a tall, inaccessible tower. This serves as a more effective visual landmark, saves development time, and avoids misleading the player, while still allowing for easter eggs to be seen from afar.
key_stories.key_quote: That almost feels like this building is a red herring now. I don't really like it that much.
